subject: Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: I have to agree with Paige.  The numbers are meaningless to me.  I read and write QS on a regular basis and have not looked at the manual in many years - even
messageBody:
I have to agree with Paige. The numbers are meaningless to me. I read and write QS on a regular basis and have not looked at the manual in many years - even if I could find it again!

Please folks, use the letter names - at least they mean something to the likes of us.

thanks

Moira

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> I believe that your discussion would be easier to follow for those in
> this group if you used the names given the letters as opposed to using
> the numbers. I don't carry the QS alphabet around with me on a sheet of
> paper and I suspect most of us don't. I never learned the letters by
> numbers. I suppose we could refer to "m" as "#13," but most people
> don't do so.
>
> Just an suggestion.
>
> Regards,
>
> Paige
>
>
> On 4/10/2013 4:02 PM, stratocat6969 wrote:
> >
> > Scott,
> >
> > I will do that. Thanks for a very clear explanation.
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, "guanolto" <scott@> wrote:
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, "stratocat6969" <john-> Yes,
> > I'm from Ontario, and I can see that I may gravitate to #34 and not
> > worry too much about the subtleties of #32 and #33. There are some
> > minor differences in how I pronounce those, but #34 does the trick in
> > most cases. I am preserving #32+#25 as I find it easier to write, and
> > I just treat it as a single sound.
> > >
> > > /Hi John,
> > >
> > > Since you're starting out I want to recommend taking a careful look
> > at your usage of #32/33/34: These represent three different sounds in
> > British English which have largely converged in American and Canadian
> > English. If you're from Ontario, then I'm guessing that your
> > pronunciation is extremely similar to mine in California.
> > >
> > > The vowel which letter #33 represents is basically the same as for
> > #32, except that with #33 you're also rounding your lips. (Most people
> > don't realize that.) The sound of letter #33 occurs frequently in
> > Britain, as well as New York / New Jersey / New England. In my
> > pronunciation the #33 never occurs at all, as it's totally replaced by
> > #32. In my speaking the sound of #34 is also almost completely
> > replaced by #32; I have the #32 sound only before an "l" or an "r",
> > and in dipthongs (in which case it's not written in QS, of course,
> > since it has specific letters for diphthongs).
> > >
> > > Anyway, just want to encourage you to look carefully at those,
> > regardless of what conclusions you reach.
> > >
> > > Kind Regards,
> > >
> > > Scott
> > >
> >
> >
>
>
> --
> "Socialism is a philosophy of failure, the creed of ignorance, and the gospel of envy, its inherent virtue is the equal sharing of misery." --- Winston Churchill
>
